qas.question: What type of documents does a textual critic usually analyze?

answers.text: a manuscript copy, several or many copies, but not the original document

qas.question: What is the proper name for textual scholarship?
Why are there differences in ancient copies of the same text?

answers.text: Ancient scribes made alterations when copying manuscripts by hand

qas.question: What do textual critics call a revised edition of a text?
What type of edition does a textual critic usually analyze?
What is the goal of the textual author?
What is the proper name for textual profession?

plausible_answers.text: the textual critic might seek to reconstruct the original text

qas.question: Why are there differences in modern copies of the same text?
What do textual critics call a perfectly translated edition of a text?

context: Textual criticism is a branch of textual scholarship, <a1_0>philology<a1_0/>, and literary criticism that is concerned with the identification of textual variants in either manuscripts or printed books. <a2_0>Ancient scribes made alterations when copying manuscripts by hand<a2_0/>. Given <a0_0>a manuscript copy, several or many copies, but not the original document<a0_0/>, <b7_0>the textual critic might seek to <b5_0>reconstruct the original text<b7_0/><b5_0/> (<b6_0>the archetype<b6_0/> or <b8_0>autograph<b8_0/>) as closely as possible. The same processes can be used to attempt to reconstruct intermediate versions, or <a3_0>recensions<a3_0/>, of a document's transcription history. The ultimate objective of the textual critic's work is the production of a "<b4_0>critical edition<b4_0/>" containing a scholarly curated text.
